Preonus Framework — Ultra-fast Java framework with build-time dependency injection, zero reflection, pre-generated DI graph, and sub-200ms startup time. Modern alternative to Spring, Micronaut, and Quarkus with AOT compilation and Undertow runtime.
Discover why we renamed our framework from Korus to Preonus, and the meaning behind the new name rooted in particle physics and Latin.

Today, I'm excited to share the story of our framework's evolution—not just in code, but in identity. What began as Korus has transformed into Preonus, a name that better reflects our mission and philosophy.
documents.s: From Korus to Preonus: The Story Behind Our Name

documents.t: As the framework matured, it became clear that we needed a name that captured its fundamental nature: breaking down complexity to its most basic, powerful elements. We wanted something that embodied the idea of fundamental building blocks—the foundation upon which everything else is constructed. That's when we discovered the perfect fit: Preonus.
Preonus is a portmanteau with deep scientific and linguistic roots:

In particle physics, preons are hypothetical subatomic, point-like particles proposed in the 1970s as the fundamental constituents of quarks and leptons. While quarks and leptons were once considered the most basic particles, preon theory suggests there might be an even deeper layer—an ultimate foundation from which everything is built. This perfectly mirrors our framework's philosophy: Fundamental — Everything reduces to the simplest, most essential components Point-like precision — No bloat, no unnecessary abstraction Building blocks — The foundation upon which complex systems are constructed Compile-time over runtime — Resolve everything at the deepest level, before execution Just as preons (if they exist) would be the ultimate constituents of matter, Preonus aims to be the ultimate foundation for Java applications—stripped down to pure compile-time logic with zero runtime magic.

The suffix "us" comes from Latin, often denoting: Collective unity — A framework that brings components together Belonging — A community of developers building with the same philosophy Plurality — Many parts working as one cohesive whole In Latin grammar, "-us" is a common noun ending that conveys substance and completeness. Combined with "Preon," it creates a name that feels both scientific and human.

At its core, Preonus is about: Fundamentals first — Build on the strongest possible foundation Compile-time everything — Resolve complexity before runtime Zero magic — Transparent, deterministic behavior Maximum performance — Remove every unnecessary layer The name Preonus embodies this perfectly. It's a framework built on the idea that great software starts with fundamental building blocks, assembled with precision at compile time.

Whether you knew us as Korus or are just discovering Preonus, we're excited to have you on this journey. The name has changed, but our mission remains: to build the fastest, most transparent Java framework—one that treats compile-time as the ultimate building block for modern applications. 👉 GitHub: https://github.com/preonus-projects/ Welcome to Preonus. Let's build something fundamental together.

Most Java frameworks use runtime DI, where objects are created and wired when the application starts. This works — but it's slow, unpredictable, and memory-heavy. Preonus takes a different approach: All dependency injection is generated at compile time. No reflection. No proxies. No classpath scanning.
Build-time DI solves three major problems:
Runtime DI frameworks scan the classpath and perform reflection when the app boots. Preonus eliminates this entirely.
Many DI issues (circular dependencies, missing beans) are discovered only when you run the app. Preonus validates the entire DI graph at compile time.
Reflection metadata, runtime registries, proxies — all reduce performance. Preonus generates pure Java code instead.

During compilation, the Preonus processor: Scans your source code Builds an internal DI model Sorts beans with a topological algorithm Generates: Constructor injection code Method injection code Singleton registries Route metadata A full PreonusMain bootstrap class Everything is resolved before your application even runs.
documents.s: How Preonus Generates the DI Graph

documents.t: public final class UserService$$PreonusBean { private final UserRepository repo; public UserService$$PreonusBean(UserRepository repo) { this.repo = repo; } public UserService get() { return new UserService(repo); } }
Build-Time Dependency Injection for Ultra-Fast Java Applications Preonus Framework is a modern Java framework designed around one core idea:

Reflection, classpath scanning, proxies, and runtime bean creation all slow down traditional Java frameworks. Preonus eliminates all of them by generating: Dependency wiring DI registries Routing metadata Bootstrapping code during compilation, not at runtime. The result: 120–250 ms startup time ~50 MB memory footprint Zero reflection Deterministic, safe DI graph Lightweight Undertow runtime
documents.s: Move everything possible to compile time.

documents.t: While working with Spring Boot and Micronaut, I noticed a common issue: Even build-time DI frameworks keep some runtime magic. Some still rely on reflection, some use proxies, some still scan packages. This inspired the architecture of Preonus: Pure annotation processing Pure compile-time registry generation No runtime analysis No surprises Preonus aims to bring: The developer experience of Spring The performance of Quarkus/Micronaut And a clean, minimal runtime
Preonus consists of two independent modules:
Responsible for: Scanning source code Building the DI graph Performing Jandex indexing Generating wiring and route registries Auto-generating PreonusMain
A lightweight Undertow-based runtime that: Loads pre-generated classes instantly Does not use reflection Does not scan the classpath Boots in under 0.25 seconds
20,000+ lines of Java code Two-module architecture Stable build-time DI engine Fast Jandex-based lookup Hibernate + HikariCP integration

Multi-module architecture (Core, Web, Data) Preonus CLI (“preonus new app”) Simpler configuration API New Data access module Build-time validation improvements Preonus is now open to the Java community. I built it to solve real problems, and I’m excited to see what developers create with it. 👉 GitHub: https://github.com/preonus-projects/
December 1, 2025 · 2 min read Vinit Shinde Creator of Preonus Framework

Reflection, classpath scanning, proxies, and runtime bean creation all slow down traditional Java frameworks. Preonus eliminates all of them by generating: Dependency wiring DI registries Routing metadata Bootstrapping code during compilation, not at runtime.
documents.s: Move everything possible to compile time.

documents.t: Hello everyone! I’m Vinit Shinde from Pune, currently in my final year at PICT. This blog is a small part of my story as a developer and the journey that eventually led to the creation of the Preonus Java Framework.
documents.s: My Journey into Java and the Story Behind Preonus

documents.t: Right after completing my 12th, I directly jumped into programming. I didn’t explore multiple languages—I started straight with Java, and that became my world. The biggest influence behind my entry into programming was my cousins. They guided me, motivated me, and pushed me toward Java when I didn’t even fully understand what programming actually was. Looking back, choosing Java as my first language was one of the best decisions I’ve ever made.

As I got deeper into the language, I began to explore: Modern Java frameworks Real-world projects End-to-end development Deployment pipelines I still remember the moment when I built and deployed a complete project using a modern framework—that’s when I felt truly confident. That’s when I realized: "Yes, I can build real engineering systems." Since then, I’ve built over 50+ public GitHub repositories, constantly improving my skills and learning everything from the ground up.

India has a massive developer ecosystem, especially around Java, but one thing always felt missing: We didn’t have our own Java framework. That thought stayed with me. And one day, I decided: "If something doesn’t exist, I will build it myself." That’s how Preonus started. Preonus is my attempt to bring something fresh, fast, and developer-friendly to the Java world, built with a strong vision and the belief that Indian developers can create world-class open-source tools.

My dream is simple: In the next 5 years, Preonus should become one of the top Java frameworks in the world. Not just another project—but something developers love, trust, and use confidently. This is just the beginning.

If you're reading this: Start early Learn consistently Build fearlessly You don’t need a perfect background or perfect conditions. You just need passion, discipline, and the courage to start. Thank you for reading. This journey has shaped me as a developer, and Preonus is the biggest step of that journey. The best part is still ahead.

To build the fastest dependency injection framework for the modern era, we need tools that match that ambition. Today, we are announcing that our project is moving its minimum requirement to Java 25. While many projects still use Java 17, we found that staying on older versions forced us to use "hacks" and heavy third-party libraries that slowed down the development and performance of the framework.

Java 17 was a great milestone, but for modern framework development, it lacks the native power available in the latest releases. Sticking to a Java 17 baseline would mean: Heavy Dependencies: We would be forced to keep using external libraries like ASM or ByteBuddy for bytecode manipulation. Java 25 provides this natively. More Boilerplate: Java 17 lacks the advanced Pattern Matching and Record features that make our internal code clean and high-performing. Slower Startup: Java 17 doesn't support the new "Compact Object Headers" or the refined Virtual Thread stability that makes modern applications scale effortlessly.
By switching to Java 25, we have unlocked three major "superpowers" that improve every application built with our tools:
documents.s: What makes Java 25 better for this Framework?

documents.t: In Java 17, reading or generating a class file required a third-party library. In Java 25, we use the Standard Class-File API. This makes our build-time processing smaller, faster, and much more stable across different environments.

Java 25 introduces Compact Object Headers, which reduce the memory footprint of every single object. For a framework that manages thousands of components, this translates to a significant reduction in heap memory usage automatically.

We now leverage the new Stable Values API. This tells the JVM that once a dependency is injected, it will never change. This allows the JIT compiler to optimize your code as if you used static final constants, making your application run at peak hardware speed. We are building for the next 10 years of Java, not the last 10.

Welcome to Preonus Framework! This guide will help you understand what makes Preonus unique and how to get started building ultra-fast Java applications. ⚡ Startup Time 100-250ms 10x faster than Spring Boot

🚀 Ultra-Fast Startup Applications start in milliseconds, not seconds 💎 Zero Reflection No runtime introspection overhead 🎯 Type Safety Catch errors at compile time 📦 Small Footprint Minimal memory consumption 🔧 Zero Config No main class required ☕ Familiar API Spring-style annotations
Applications start in milliseconds, not seconds
No runtime introspection overhead
Catch errors at compile time
Minimal memory consumption
No main class required
Spring-style annotations

Build-Time vs Runtime Build Time Preonus analyzes your code, generates dependency graphs, creates bean wiring code, and produces optimized bytecode - all during compilation → Runtime Your application just loads pre-generated classes and starts instantly. No scanning, no reflection, no proxies

Build Time Preonus analyzes your code, generates dependency graphs, creates bean wiring code, and produces optimized bytecode - all during compilation → Runtime Your application just loads pre-generated classes and starts instantly. No scanning, no reflection, no proxies

Preonus vs Popular Frameworks Preonus Spring Boot Micronaut Quarkus DI Style Build-time Runtime Compile-time Build-time Startup Time 100-200ms 1500-4500ms 500-1200ms 300-900ms Memory Usage ~50MB 150-250MB 50-150MB 40-90MB Reflection Zero Heavy Minimal Some

Preonus Spring Boot Micronaut Quarkus DI Style Build-time Runtime Compile-time Build-time Startup Time 100-200ms 1500-4500ms 500-1200ms 300-900ms Memory Usage ~50MB 150-250MB 50-150MB 40-90MB Reflection Zero Heavy Minimal Some

Now that you understand what Preonus is, let's get it installed: Installation Guide - Set up Preonus in your project Quick Start Tutorial - Build your first application Ready to Build? Jump straight to the Quick Start Tutorial to create your first Preonus application in under 5 minutes!
Let’s compare the most popular modern Java frameworks.
documents.s: Preonus vs Spring Boot vs Micronaut vs Quarkus

documents.t: Framework Startup Time Spring Boot 1500–2500ms Micronaut 600–1200ms Quarkus 800–1500ms Preonus 120–250ms
Framework DI Style Reflection? Compile-Time? Spring Boot Runtime DI Yes Partial Micronaut Compile-Time DI No Yes Quarkus Build-Time DI Some Mostly Preonus Build-Time DI Some Mostly
Heavy runtime logic Massive ecosystem Easiest to use
Build-time friendly Faster than Spring Requires extra modules
GraalVM optimized Build-time profiling Complex stack
Simpler than Micronaut/Quarkus Faster than all of them Pure compile-time graph Clean Undertow runtime
Use Case Best Choice Enterprise backend Spring Boot Serverless Preonus / Quarkus Microservices Preonus / Micronaut CLI apps Preonus AOT native images Preonus / Quarkus
Preonus is ideal when you want: Fast startup Low memory usage Deterministic DI Zero reflection runtime Preonus stands as a next-generation framework built for modern Java workloads.
This guide walks you through installing Preonus Framework in your project.
Before installing Preonus, ensure you have: Java 25+ or Kotlin 1.9+ Maven 3.6+ or Gradle 8.0+ An IDE (IntelliJ IDEA or VS Code recommended) Java17+Kotlin1.9+Maven3.6+Gradle8.0+

Add Preonus to your project by configuring the build system. Preonus uses a Build Parent for Maven and a standard plugin-style approach for Gradle. Project Configuration Maven Gradle <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"> <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion> <parent> <groupId>io.preonus</groupId> <artifactId>preonus-build-parent</artifactId> <version>1.0.0-SNAPSHOT</version> </parent> <artifactId>my-preonus-app</artifactId> <dependencies> <dependency> <groupId>io.preonus</groupId> <artifactId>core-starter</artifactId> </dependency> <dependency> <groupId>ch.qos.logback</groupId> <artifactId>logback-classic</artifactId> </dependency> </dependencies> <build> <plugins> <plugin> <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId> <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId> <configuration> <compilerArgs> <arg>-Apreonus.processing.verbose=true</arg> </compilerArgs> </configuration> </plugin> </plugins> </build> </project> plugins { id 'java' id 'io.preonus.plugin' version '1.0.0' } group = 'com.example' version = '1.0.0-SNAPSHOT' repositories { mavenCentral() } dependencies { implementation 'io.preonus:core-starter' runtimeOnly 'ch.qos.logback:logback-classic' // Annotation Processor annotationProcessor 'io.preonus:preonus-processor' } tasks.withType(JavaCompile) { options.compilerArgs << "-Apreonus.processing.verbose=true" }

Preonus is designed to be lean. You do not need a Main class; the framework automatically generates the entry point during compilation. my-preonus-app/ ├── src/ │ ├── main/ │ │ ├── java/ (or kotlin/) │ │ │ └── com/example/ │ │ │ ├── controllers/ │ │ │ │ └── HelloController.java │ │ │ └── services/ │ │ │ └── HelloService.java │ │ └── resources/ │ │ └── application.properties └── pom.xml (or build.gradle)

Create a simple service to verify the build-time wiring and code generation. HelloService Verification Java Kotlin package com.example.services; import io.preonus.core.annotation.Service; @Service public class HelloService { public String sayHello(String name) { return "Hello, " + name + "!"; } } package com.example.services import io.preonus.core.annotation.Service @Service class HelloService { fun sayHello(name: String): String { return "Hello, $name!" } } Build and compile your project: Build Command Maven Gradle mvn clean compile📋Copy ./gradlew classes📋Copy

Enable Annotation Processing: Settings → Build, Execution, Deployment → Compiler → Annotation Processors Check "Enable annotation processing" Kotlin Support: Ensure the KAPT or KSP plugin is enabled if using Kotlin.
Install the Preonus VS Code extension for enhanced support: code --install-extension preonus.preonus-initializer📋Copy
Now that Preonus is installed: Quick Start Tutorial - Build your first app in under 5 minutes.

Preonus Framework is a Build-Time Dependency Injection framework designed for ultra-fast Java applications. It removes reflection, classpath scanning, and runtime dependency wiring entirely — delivering performance comparable to Quarkus and Micronaut while preserving a clean, Spring-like developer experience. info Created and maintained by Vinit Shinde (Aug 2025 – Present). GitHub Repository: preonus-projects

Preonus is a modern Java framework built around annotation processing, compile-time bean creation, and a lightweight runtime. All routing, dependency wiring, configuration metadata, and validation logic is generated during compilation, not at runtime. Key Benefits Zero Reflection - No runtime introspection overhead Zero Classpath Scanning - Everything resolved at compile time Zero Dynamic Proxies - Direct method calls only Instant Startup Times - Applications start in milliseconds Low Memory Footprint - Minimal runtime overhead

Build-Time Engine Runtime Engine Preonus Processor​ Responsible for: Annotation scanning & model building Generating bean wiring at compile time Creating DI registries Performing circular dependency detection Generating route metadata Jandex-based indexing for fast lookups Auto-generating a PreonusMain boot class Preonus Framework​ A lightweight runtime that: Loads pre-generated classes instantly Does not perform any reflection Does not scan classpath packages Uses static indexes + generated registries Boots in ~0.10s – 0.20s

Responsible for: Annotation scanning & model building Generating bean wiring at compile time Creating DI registries Performing circular dependency detection Generating route metadata Jandex-based indexing for fast lookups Auto-generating a PreonusMain boot class
A lightweight runtime that: Loads pre-generated classes instantly Does not perform any reflection Does not scan classpath packages Uses static indexes + generated registries Boots in ~0.10s – 0.20s

Preonus generates concrete bean classes and wiring logic during compilation: Direct constructor/method injection written into generated Java files Deterministic topological sort for bean initialization Compile-time detection of circular dependencies Complete removal of runtime scanning and proxies This gives Preonus its signature performance benefits. Check out the documentation to learn more about Preonus Framework.
All commands can be accessed via Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P).

mvnw test — Run all tests

View Generated Registry Count Components

The Preonus VS Code extension utilizes the Maven Wrapper (mvnw) to execute build tasks. For the extension to function correctly, your project must contain the following file structure: project-root/ ├── mvnw ├── mvnw.cmd └── .mvn/ └── wrapper/ └── maven-wrapper.properties Note: If these files are missing, the extension will be unable to run builds or execute lifecycle commands.
The Preonus Framework requires Java 25 or higher.
Set the JAVA_HOME environment variable via the command line: setx JAVA_HOME "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-21"
Export JAVA_HOME in your shell profile (e.g., .bashrc or .zshrc): export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-21-openjdk
To confirm your installation is correct, run: java -version

To use the Preonus extension, ensure your environment meets the following criteria: Visual Studio Code: Version 1.80.0 or higher. Supported Operating Systems: Windows macOS Linux Recommendation: For the best development experience, ensure the official Java and Maven extensions for VS Code are also installed.
Let's build a simple REST API in under 5 minutes using Preonus Framework!
A REST API with: Health check endpoint User management service Dependency injection Sub-200ms startup time

First, create a service to handle business logic: UserService - Business Logic Java Kotlin package com.example.services; import io.preonus.core.annotation.Service; import java.util.List; import java.util.ArrayList; @Service public class UserService { private final List<String> users = new ArrayList<>(); public UserService() { // Initialize with sample data users.add("Alice"); users.add("Bob"); } public List<String> getAllUsers() { return new ArrayList<>(users); } public void addUser(String name) { users.add(name); } public String getUser(int index) { if (index >= 0 && index < users.size()) { return users.get(index); } return null; } } package com.example.services import io.preonus.core.annotation.Service @Service class UserService { private val users = mutableListOf("Alice", "Bob") fun getAllUsers(): List<String> = users.toList() fun addUser(name: String) { users.add(name) } fun getUser(index: Int): String? { return users.getOrNull(index) } }

Now create a controller to expose REST endpoints: UserController - REST API Java Kotlin package com.example.controllers; import com.example.services.UserService; import io.preonus.web.annotation.RestController; import io.preonus.web.annotation.GetMapping; import io.preonus.web.annotation.PostMapping; import io.preonus.web.annotation.PathVariable; import io.preonus.web.annotation.RequestBody; import io.preonus.web.exception.NotFoundException; import java.util.List; @RestController("/api") public class UserController { private final UserService userService; public UserController(UserService userService) { this.userService = userService; } @GetMapping("/users") public List<String> getAllUsers() { return userService.getAllUsers(); } @GetMapping("/users/{id}") public String getUser(@PathVariable int id) { String user = userService.getUser(id); if (user == null) { throw new NotFoundException("User not found"); } return user; } @PostMapping("/users") public void addUser(@RequestBody String name) { userService.addUser(name); } @GetMapping("/health") public String health() { return "OK"; } } package com.example.controllers import com.example.services.UserService import io.preonus.web.annotation.RestController import io.preonus.web.annotation.GetMapping import io.preonus.web.annotation.PostMapping import io.preonus.web.annotation.PathVariable import io.preonus.web.annotation.RequestBody import io.preonus.web.exception.NotFoundException @RestController("/api") class UserController( private val userService: UserService ) { @GetMapping("/users") fun getAllUsers() = userService.getAllUsers() @GetMapping("/users/{id}") fun getUser(@PathVariable id: Int): String { return userService.getUser(id) ?: throw NotFoundException("User not found") } @PostMapping("/users") fun addUser(@RequestBody name: String) { userService.addUser(name) } @GetMapping("/health") fun health() = "OK" }
That's it! No need to create a main class. Preonus auto-generates the entry point. Build and Run Maven Gradle mvn clean compile mvn exec:java ./gradlew clean build ./gradlew run

Your application is now running! Test the endpoints: curl http://localhost:8080/api/health📋Copy curl http://localhost:8080/api/users📋Copy curl -X POST http://localhost:8080/api/users -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d "Charlie"📋Copy
🚀 Startup Time 185ms Your app is ready in under 200ms!

During compilation, Preonus: Scanned your @Service and @RestController annotations Generated dependency injection code Created route mappings Built a complete application entry point Eliminated all reflection overhead You're Ready! You now have a working Preonus application with ultra-fast startup and zero reflection overhead!

Check pom.xml: Ensure a valid pom.xml exists in your project root. Refresh: Click Refresh Projects in the Preonus dashboard. Workspace: Make sure the project folder is correctly added to your VS Code workspace.

Check Java Installation: Run the following command to ensure Java is accessible: java -version Environment Variables: Verify that JAVA_HOME is correctly set in your environment variables. Maven Wrapper Permissions: If using Linux or macOS, ensure the Maven Wrapper is executable: chmod +x mvnw Syntax Check: Confirm there are no syntax errors in your pom.xml file.

Port Availability: Ensure port 8080 (or your configured port) is available and not in use by another application. Check Logs: Review the Integrated Terminal for specific error messages. Pre-compile: Try running a manual build before starting to ensure dependencies are resolved: ./mvnw compile Extension Freeze: If the extension becomes unresponsive, try restarting VS Code.
For help, reporting issues, or providing suggestions, please reach out via the following channels: Email: preonus.framework@gmail.com

A complete project management dashboard and control panel for Preonus Framework inside Visual Studio Code. This extension streamlines your entire Preonus development workflow — from project creation to lifecycle management, builds, testing, dependency analysis, and code generation insights — all inside VS Code.

Manage Preonus Java projects visually Start, stop, build, and test with one click Explore source code, components, and dependencies Track generated registry and component statistics Zero CLI required for daily development
